entry.title: Combined summary - Error handling in payment protocol (BIP-0070 and BIP-0072)
entry.summary: The email correspondence between Gavin Andresen and Ross Nicoll centers around concerns over error handling in the payment protocol specifications. Ross proposes formalizing processes to ensure consistency, either by editing the existing BIP or writing up a new one. He recommends having guidance for merchants on how to handle errors processing Payment messages, such as having a fixed maximum size of 10MB and a defined maximum time to wait to avoid DDoS via connection holding.Gavin agrees with the need for consistency but believes that wallet software should be free to give users the best experience. For transport failures or 500 status codes, he recommends retrying after a delay of 30-60 seconds, while for 400 status codes, the request should not be repeated, and the user should be alerted with a copy of the Payment message saved to be resent later. For 300 status codes, it is considered safe to follow redirects. Regarding repeatedly receiving the same Payment message, Gavin thinks this should be left to implementations to work out.Ross also expresses caution regarding embedding files into the payment request for security reasons. He suggests embedding PaymentRequest directly into web pages through the <iframe> tag, which could potentially eliminate the need for BIP0072 and improve user interface integration. Mike Hearn points out that PaymentRequests are limited to 50,000 bytes and that it might be nice to have images and other elements in payment requests but the current version should suffice with a 50kb limit.Lastly, the email thread discusses potential timing issues with transactions. Ross wonders whether a merchant system should hold the connection or send a PaymentACK with a memo indicating payment has been seen on the relay network but is not yet confirmed. Gavin believes waiting more than a second or three to get "your payment has been received and is being processed" is terrible UI, and the user should get feedback right away. Overall, the discussion offers several suggestions for improving the payment protocol specifications to handle unexpected problems while sending or receiving Payment messages and ensuring consistency in error handling.
